THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1883.

OUR WANTS AND OUR GRIEVANCES

It is now more than six months since we first called the attention of the Dominion Government to some of the prominent requirements of this portion of the Province. The time has passed and there is no prospect of an immediate settlement. The memorial which had been prepared by two of our prominent residents at the special request of the Premier, and presented to the Government a year ago last spring, which would have satisfied the present requirements of this district, has been allowed to fall into desuetude. Since then another memorial—this time addressed to the House of Commons—has been prepared and presented by the inhabitants on the same subject, which was presented to Parliament by a prominent supporter of the Government in the House. In the meantime, however, the question has been raised again, and a new petition has been presented by Mr. Blair, the leader of the Opposition. It is now time to inquire what has been the result? Literally nothing—except the expenditure of thousands of dollars. The Government has not yet answered the petition, nor has any satisfactory reply been given to the many grievances which have been so long laboring under. PROSPECTUS OF THE Prince Albert Directory AND BUSINESS GUIDE.

It is proposed to issue a Business Directory for the Town of Prince Albert, and the County of Nipissing, containing which will contain the advertisements of each business establishment, to be in accordance with the rules and a descriptive list of streets.

The press will contain a history of Prince Albert, its present condition, future prospects, together with a statement of the year's crops, as far as they can be ascertained for the District of Toronto, and also a statement of the number of bushels per acre, increase over last year's crop, population of District, and other useful information, written by a well known journalist.

About 500 or more copies will be published (according to the response received) next week, and distributed throughout the Dominion and the Mother Country.

It is expected that by this means, benefit will result, not only to each individual advertiser and subscriber, but that the whole country will become better informed, and that the best at home and abroad, and healthy emigration encouraged to this country.

Price of advertisements, while paper is good, will be 25 cents per square inch, with notice of opposite page, and two copies given free.

THE NORTH WEST COUNCIL

Petitions Presented Other Business.

Saskatoon, Aug. 30. The following petitions were presented:

By Mr. Brown—Similar petition regarding the sale of liquor.

By Mr. White—Similar petition regarding the sale of liquor.

The above were referred to Standing Committee on Municipal Affairs.

By Mr. White—Petition of members of the legal profession praying for an ordinance regulating their profession.

Report of Special Committee on the petition relating to the sale of ale and porter in the Territories. Minority report made objections to such step.

Bill to enable the Board of Health of Medicine Hat to purchase land presented by Mr. Macdonald, read first time.

A bill to prevent the sale of stolen horses, read a second time.

Mr. Macdonald obtained leave to bring in a bill to amend the revenue respecting the sale of beer and ale.

His Honor presented a bill respecting infectious diseases of horses and cattle.

Read a second time.

The Council resolved itself into committees of the whole to report respecting the matters mentioned in the bills.

Mr. Macdonald supported the prayer of the petitioners, arguing that to have light beer would be a great benefit to the temperance movement. At present the very strongest whisky was brought in, and even poorer classes consume while the freight kept other classes away.

Mr. Oliver made a speech against the petition.

Col. MacLeod thought the majority of the people were in favor of keeping things as they now stand.

Mr. Campbell also supported the petition on the ground that good wholesome beer would be a blessing to the people.

Col. Richardson also spoke against the petition.

Mr. Ross advocated the petition. They said whisky brought in in every shape, and the Mounted Police were incapable of keeping it out, and could not keep it out, and therefore it was better to allow light beers to be manufactured.
